Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Fix minification failures and delete unused assets" (#7963) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
- Add tests to detect minification failures in the future. Basically WebGrease uses an older view the JS and CSS syntax. I had to update to the latest WebGrase to address CSS minification failures.
- Revert newer JavaScript syntax that breaks minification
- Minify some unminified files
- Delete an unused copy of jQuery UI
- Delete unused syntax highlighter CSS

Address https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/3107

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Print which feed a package was resolved from" (#9479) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Transferred from https://github.com/dotnet/docs/issues/12713

The request is to show which feed a package was resolved from when .NET Core CLI command `dotnet restore` is run either explicitly or implicitly.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "nuget.exe 5.5+ fails to restore with MSBuild 14 or below" (#9458) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): nuget.exe

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 5.5.1

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):

VS version (if appropriate):

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: 5.4.X

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. `nuget.exe restore -MSBuildVersion 14.0`

Fails with the error:
```
C:\Users\jeffkl\AppData\Local\Temp\NuGetScratch\npvhljmi.kme.nugetrestore.targets(435,34):
error MSB4092: An unexpected token ")" was found at character position 28 in condition
"@(PackageReference->Count()) > 0". [D:\AspNetWithNet35\AspNetWithNet35\AspNetWithNet35.csproj]
```

This was introduced by my change: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/commit/1ce56a3cd779ec4ebae39a1b0ce3f7ccc3310584#diff-3b0018f61173d0adf1ba163a23821381R434
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3135

It turns out that the item function `Count()` was only added in MSBuild 14.0 Update 3.  So when using an older version of MSBuild, we can't use this logic.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add a context menu for PM UI in VS OE" (#9428) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "nuget.exe update -self -Source https://feed" (#1783) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
nuget.exe update -Self is hardcoded to use nuget.org v2
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.CommandLine/Common/SelfUpdater.cs#L44

This command should be improved so that v3 sources can be used. It should also be possible to update from a local v3 server or pre-release feed such as the nuget-build feed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet command line times out on bad internet connection while other services operate correctly." (#9478) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
I live out in the boonies and have an internet connection that has a very unique problem.  If my internet reaches peak bandwidth usage on multiple connections it will effectively drop to basically no bandwidth available.  This is 100% reproducible by uploading a large file.  I will go from 12Mbps down, 3Mbps up, to less than 1Mbps down and up.  
Now that I am working from home, this has caused me a unique problem when running my team's Docker compose files, which builds 10+ services using `dotnet test` and `dotnet restore` on OSX.  
What runs in 30 seconds for my teammates, ran for over an hour on my machine without reaching the end.

It's very worth noting that this problem with my internet only occurs *when uploading a large file or using `dotnet restore`* and not at any other time.  It *does not occur from reaching my peak download speeds*.

## Example errors: 

> Failed to download package 'Microsoft.NetCore.Analyzers.2.9.8' from 'https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/microsoft.netcore.analyzers/2.9.8/microsoft.netcore.analyzers.2.9.8.nupkg'.
>    Received an unexpected EOF or 0 bytes from the transport stream.
>   Failed to download package 'runtime.native.System.4.0.0' from 'https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/runtime.native.system/4.0.0/runtime.native.system.4.0.0.nupkg'.
>   The download of 'https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/runtime.native.system/4.0.0/runtime.native.system.4.0.0.nupkg' timed out because no data was received for 60000ms.
>     Exception of type 'System.TimeoutException' was thrown.
>   Failed to download package 'System.Xml.ReaderWriter.4.3.0' from 'https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/system.xml.readerwriter/4.3.0/system.xml.readerwriter.4.3.0.nupkg'.
>    Received an unexpected EOF or 0 bytes from the transport stream.
>   Failed to download package 'System.Runtime.4.3.0' from 'https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/system.runtime/4.3.0/system.runtime.4.3.0.nupkg'.
>   The download of 'https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/system.runtime/4.3.0/system.runtime.4.3.0.nupkg' timed out because no data was received for 60000ms.
>     Exception of type 'System.TimeoutException' was thrown.
>   Failed to download package 'System.Reflection.Primitives.4.3.0' from 'https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/system.reflection.primitives/4.3.0/system.reflection.primitives.4.3.0.nupkg'.
>   The download of 'https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/system.reflection.primitives/4.3.0/system.reflection.primitives.4.3.0.nupkg' timed out because no data was received for 60000ms.
>     Exception of type 'System.TimeoutException' was thrown.


NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):
dotnet restore

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 5.5.0.4

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 3.1.201

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): macOS Mojave 10.14.6

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Have my internet connection.

2. run `dotnet restore` on a project in an environment that does not have any nuget packages cached.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PackTask should report build error after logging errors" (#9477) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
SDK version: 3.1.201
OS: Windows 10

The `dotnet pack` command incorrectly returns an exit code of 0 even after experiencing and printing errors (where `TreatWarningsAsErrors=true` has been set). This allows Azure Pipelines (for example) to proceed to build and report success and ship software even when errors occurred during the pack.

For example, this Azure Pipeline should have failed, but proceeded after an error during pack:
https://dev.azure.com/andrewarnott/OSS/_build/results?buildId=2632&view=logs&j=2d2b3007-3c5c-5840-9bb0-2b1ea49925f3&t=f33089cd-d3fe-578c-2c5e-4ee560e10a0d

**Repro**

In any repo that uses .NET SDK 3.1.201, introduce a pack warning. For example, set the `<PackageLicenseExpression>MS-Pl</PackageLicenseExpression>` property (which has a non-canonical capitalization for the property value).

```cmd
SET TreatWarningsAsErrors=true
dotnet pack
echo %ERRORLEVEL%
```

**Expected**

A non-zero exit code

**Actual**

A zero exit code

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Test: UninstallFromPMCForPC_SucceedAsync is flaky" (#9476) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The test `NuGet.Tests.Apex.AuthorSignedPackageTestCase.UninstallFromPMCForPC_SucceedAsync(projectTemplate: ClassLibrary)` has timed out on at least two builds: [1](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3669401&view=logs&j=54d34e6c-10d1-5f6f-0d73-85c1fa19385b&t=2bc2bfed-4a11-5a5c-814b-223591eb3d53), [2](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3672284&view=logs&j=54d34e6c-10d1-5f6f-0d73-85c1fa19385b&t=2bc2bfed-4a11-5a5c-814b-223591eb3d53)

Since it times out, the test results xml doesn't get generated, which means Azure DevOps test result analysis can't help us determine how often it's happening (the Apex tests job has timed out for multiple reasons in the past)

```
     NuGet.Tests.Apex.AuthorSignedPackageTestCase.UninstallFromPMCForPC_SucceedAsync(projectTemplate: ClassLibrary) [STARTING]
     NuGet.Tests.Apex: [Long Running Test] 'NuGet.Tests.Apex.AuthorSignedPackageTestCase.UninstallFromPMCForPC_SucceedAsync', Elapsed: 00:05:04
     NuGet.Tests.Apex: [Long Running Test] 'NuGet.Tests.Apex.AuthorSignedPackageTestCase.UninstallFromPMCForPC_SucceedAsync', Elapsed: 00:10:04
     NuGet.Tests.Apex: [Long Running Test] 'NuGet.Tests.Apex.AuthorSignedPackageTestCase.UninstallFromPMCForPC_SucceedAsync', Elapsed: 00:15:05
     NuGet.Tests.Apex: [Long Running Test] 'NuGet.Tests.Apex.AuthorSignedPackageTestCase.UninstallFromPMCForPC_SucceedAsync', Elapsed: 00:20:05
     NuGet.Tests.Apex: [Long Running Test] 'NuGet.Tests.Apex.AuthorSignedPackageTestCase.UninstallFromPMCForPC_SucceedAsync', Elapsed: 00:25:05
     NuGet.Tests.Apex: [Long Running Test] 'NuGet.Tests.Apex.AuthorSignedPackageTestCase.UninstallFromPMCForPC_SucceedAsync', Elapsed: 00:30:05
     NuGet.Tests.Apex: [Long Running Test] 'NuGet.Tests.Apex.AuthorSignedPackageTestCase.UninstallFromPMCForPC_SucceedAsync', Elapsed: 00:35:05
Attempting to cancel the build...
##[error]The task has timed out.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Transitively include targets and content files from referenced packages" (#9474) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Scenario: I have a solution with many projects, which we want to publish as NuGet packages. (In addition, we want to be able to debug them in Visual Studio.)  The projects reference each other, and also reference other NuGet packages, e.g. to bring unmanaged libraries to project output.

By default, when I reference a NuGet package, its build targets and content files are brought to the first referencing project, but not to the projects that reference it. The same happens if I reference a package indirectly (project X references package A, package A references package B, package B has build targets and/or content files).
* I am happy about this behavior, because Visual Studio automatically copies the build output of the project to the referencing project. There is no need to execute the targets again in the referencing project; in addition, if they were executed again, this could make the build non-deterministic (if the build target depends on some property, it would need to be set in the referencing project as well).

But this also causes the build target to be excluded by the package generated by `dotnet pack` / `msbuild /t:Pack`. The generated package has the following dependency declarations:
```<dependency id="PackageName" version="PackageVersion" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />```
So the the package built from the project will ignore the build targets of the referenced package - if I reference this package in another project, they won't be executed (the files won't be brought to the project output).

Option 1: Set `PrivateAssets`. This is a problem, because I have to set this for every package and project reference in the solution, and there can be perhaps a hundred of them. In addition, this changes the behavior during the build, causing them to be executed in every referencing project. (As above, I only want the target to be executed once, and also I want it to be executed once if the generated package is referenced by another project.)

Option 2: Use `buildTransitive`. This requires me to modify every package in question, which may not be under my control. In addition, what will happen if another project references my project? Will this cause the transitive target to be executed again by the referencing project? (Again, this is behavior which I don't want.)

Option 3: Hook to some MsBuild target and modify the generated nuspec file before packing. I didn't succeed with that. If I run `msbuild /t:Pack`, then if I execute my target before `GenerateNuspec`, the nuspec file doesn't exist yet; if I run it after GenerateNuspec, it is too late because it has already been packed into the package. (In addition - as far as I know - there is no property containing the location of the nuspec file.) If I run `msbuild /t:GenerateNuspec;Pack`, it doesn't pack anything.

What other options are there? I want to preserve the default behavior of Visual Studio when building (to not bring the imported targets to referencing projects, and to instead depend on the copying of the output directory), but I also want to preserve the default behavior of NuGet (do not generate the `exclude` declarations to modify the default behavior; or, alternately, to perform arbitrary modification of the generated nuspec file and remove them before packing).

See related issues: https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/1266 , https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/3697 , https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/6388 .

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Localization][CHS][CHT] String “By” should be translated to “作者:”" (#9045) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
VS Version: D16.5\29708.193
OS Version: windows-10-enterprise-rs4-zh-cn
## Installation
1. Install a clean machine with OS: windows-10-enterprise-rs4-zh-cn
2. Install VS D16.5\29708.193: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3369922&view=results CHS/CHT
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Open Visual Studio 2019 preview.
2. Create a new Console App (.Net Core) project.
3. Right-click the project and open PM UI in Solution Explorer window.
4. Observe the translation of the author of the package (e.g. Newtonsoft.Json).
## Expected
String “by” should be translated to “作者:”.
## Actual
String “by” was translated to “由”/”依”, making the sentence incomplete as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/72142175-11e9c000-33cf-11ea-9741-c79269bd62bf.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/72317361-faaf1900-36d3-11ea-98d0-4e48b9401031.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org – Stage 1" (#42) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
## NuGet.org will temporarily remove support for TLS 1.0/1.1 on February 26, 2020

We plan to temporarily remove support for TLS 1.0/1.1 across 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each, to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. If you discover that you are impacted and cannot identify a workaround, please open an issue on the NuGet Gallery GitHub repo.

Read this blog post to learn more and to identify the test slot time in your time zone - https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/deprecating-tls-1-0-and-1-1-on-nuget-org-stage-1/
